titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. VI:30. At the Office— Two Northern Mails— None yesterday from the badness of the roads— All day absorbed in reading— North American Review, and newspapers— Business neglected— George and Mary Hellen came down to dinner. Letter from J. D. Heath Charleston— Mr and Mrs Cutts, Evening here. Vice-President indisposed— Senate chose J. Gaillard, President pro Tem— Mrs Adams unwell.

2. VII.Mr Hayward, a tutor of Harvard University here— At the Office— Buck. again about Hamburg and discriminating duties— He is going to Philadelphia— Cazenove to converse with me— Statement to be sent me of the cases, and amount required to be refunded— Disaster of the Matilda, Knap. from New-York with the French weights and measures on board. Letter to Collector of Norfolk— Letters from P. Little and Josiah Butler of H.R.— Answered. At P.U.S. with despatches from R. Rush &c. Letter from C. S. Todd— Is he to be allowed his Salary while here?— Johnson Hellen late home to dinner— Mr Wirt taken suddenly ill— Bilious Colic— Anduaga, returned from Philadelphia—

3. VI: Walked with Johnson Hellen to Georgetown. Heard Tyng. John 1.46— Left Cards at Brady’s Hotel for R. King, H. G. Otis and B. Gorham— Call on T. Cook, who broke a blood vessel in coughing last Thursday— He is feeble and feverish— Cards to Anduaga, and de Barros— Evening, writing to my Son John— Calculation of compound interest by logarithms. Waste of time in reading Newspapers— Johnson Hellen went to watch with Mr Wirt, who is better.

4. VII: Interest and Logarithms— Enquiry pursued— Stewart’s Philosophy of the human mind. At the Office— Chazotte— His town in Florida last Summer—will make a written report. Wreckers—Sugar and Coffee lands— Indians— Forests— Tropical trees— Live Oak. Olive—Vines— Answer to Call of H.R. on Ghent Treaty Commission Article 5— Evening at Mrs. French’s Concert— Dolce Concerto— Soldier tir’d— W. Pinkney. A Connnoisseur.

5. VI:30.Baldwin here— Apportionment of Representation— South American Affairs and Independence— Commercial and Political connection with them— Preble—documents to be obtained at Madrid— R. King— Apportionment— Anecdote of J. Randolph and F. C. Gray— France—discontent at our interference with her Slave-trade. I told him what we had done— Foreign Affairs— Disagreement between King of France and house of deputies— At the Office. S. Thompson. Atlas— Florida keys. Lighthouse. F. Key— Colonization Society, plan to purchase a place in Africa, through R. Rush. P.U.S. declines giving Instructions. Eve at home—increase of population. 3 per Cent per Annum. Mrs Adams taken ill, after riding out— Received several visits.

6. V:45.Cushman here with Wadsworth of Vermont, who recommends another Cushman to be a judge in Florida— Wyer here with much talk about nothing. At the Office Hoffman of Baltimore for a Passport. Short despatch to R. Rush— Eve at the Drawing-Room. M. L. Hill gave me a Letter to him from A. K. Parris.

7. VI:15. Meeting of the Commissioners of the sinking fund at the Capitol— Present, the President of the Senate, Gaillard, Chief Justice, Marshall, and Secretary of the Treasury Crawford— Attorney General Wirt, absent, from illness— And Vice-President Tompkins, having abdicated the chair of the Senate— Report of Secy. of the Treasury to the Commissioners was read, and the appended documents were examined— Report of Commissioners to Congress was signed— Three copies— One for each house of Congress and one for the Treasury— The sinking fund is itself sunk— In the Senate chamber— Spoke with Lowrie about the reappointment of Irish as Marshal for the Western District of Pennsylvania. with R. M. Johnson about W. P. Duval as Governor of Florida. with Palmer about Cushman, as judge in Florida— R. King, Chairman of Committee of Foreign Relations of Senate asked Crawford and me to meet them at the Committee-room next Monday Morning at ten O’Clock—on Commercial Affairs with France, Great-Britain and South-America— At the House of Representatives— On a partial Navy Appropriation, and the Bankrupt-Bill— Talk with many of the Members— Eustis said it was thought there would be a fight between Gilmer and D. P. Cook— House adjourned at 4. Walk with Dwight, Canning and Wilmot. Talk with Canning of Wilcocke’s case— At the Office. Voluminous despatches— Evening with Johnson Hellen at the Capitol— Barber’s Lecture upon Life— Ladies there.

8. VII: At the Office. Genl. P. B. Porter; returned from Philadelphia— The Commissioners have adjourned to meet at Utica, the 3d. of June— Barclay waits for Instructions from his Government to close the Commission— They made some progress— Dr Morse—for a Passport. Has been unwell— Genl. Duncan, with a Letter from C. J. Ingersoll, and claims of his brother Abner L. Duncan, upon the War and Treasury Departments— Captain Ballard, with Claims for hearing despatches in 1813. and for Shaler on board his ship in 1819. A great multitude of despatches more than I could read— Note in the printed Estimates. Mistake sent Maury to the Treasury— At P.U.S. Ballard’s Claims, first allowed— The other to be considered— Meeting of Members of Administration, fixed for to-morrow at one. Had company to dine— Diplomatic— Eve at Crawford’s Ball— J. Sergeant went with me, and I took him home.

9. VII:30. War dance of the Indians, in front of the President’s house— Crowd of People— The dance dull— War whoop feeble—difficulty of getting a sight of the Show— Cabinet Meeting— Wirt only absent— Views of the Executive concerning British West India trade— Also commercial Relations with France— The system hitherto proved not to be changed— Crawford hinted at additional restrictions; but they were not thought advisable— South-American Affairs— Ardour for recognition cooled— Members of Congress not so zealous— Recognition if at-all, not till towards the close of this Session of Congress— Meeting broke up after 4— Evening calculations with George— Compound Interest, and progressive population of U.S.

10. VII:15. Snow— Heard Thacher of New-Haven, a Methodist at the Capitol. 1. Corinthians 2.2. Call on Hendricks who is ill in bed— Relapse of Chills and fever, and remittent fever. Talk with J. W. Taylor there— Postmaster at Albany— Reported new rule of nomination by the Senators— Visits to Captain Ballard and Finch, by Cards— Mail— Note from J. Randolph— Evening visits from Mitchell of S.C. and R. B. Jones— Census Calculations.

11. VI: Note from P.U.S. Nomination of A. Ware again—again delayed. At the Capitol. Met with Crawford the Committee of foreign relations of the Senate— R. King— Jas Barbour.N. Macon, Brown of Louisiana, and Elliott of Georgia— Relations with G. Britain with France, and with South-America— Macon’s notions—fancies— Read Gallatin’s Letters; and those of Torres— At the House— Bankrupt-Bill— Hemphill and Colden’s speeches. Gave S. Smith, Nourse Declaration, against the Note in the Estimates— Colden gave me a paper of complaint against the returns of the Census— Cast up with Gales the aggregate of New-York; found it correct— J. Randolph— Spoke about Documents— At the Office. Many despatches— Evening—preparing Census Tables.

12. VI.Ryland here with Thacher of New-Haven— Subscription for rebuilding the Methodist Church there— Baldwin—about the manufactury Census papers— Wants a digest made this Session. Thinks T. Coxe too old— Two Clerks could make it in a Month. He would superintend them— Ward of Boston here— Genl. P. B. Porter at the Office, with a Letter concerning the proceedings of the Commissioners of Ghent Treaty. Article 6. and an explanation. Ballard. His claim as bearer of despatches to be adjusted— That for conveying Shaler cannot be allowed— E. B. Jackson with Jacobs and another— Letter to S. Moore— Note to J. Randolph with Books— Mrs. Adams’s birth-day 47. Evening upon Census calculations— W. Lee and Shaler here.

13. VII.Insinger here— Wishes to be introduced to the President, but cannot stay till the Drawing-room next week— Wolf-Tone—going to England next Month— Will take despatches. Passed 11. years at the Prytanée— W. Taylor— Wishes to go to Vera-Crux— Roberdeau witha nephew of Dr Blair— At the Office— Genl. P. B. Porter, with estimate of expenses of the Commission, under 7th. Article of Ghent Treaty, and explanatory Letter. John Yates—with a Letter of recommendation from Dr Kent—for an Office in the Department— No vacancy— Letters to S. Smith Chairman of Comee. of Ways and means, about the estimates— to S. Moore, of Comee. of Claims, on J. L. Cathcart’s claim on Spain, and to W. Lownde’s Chairman of Committee on Weights and measures: on price of importing Standards— Evening, upon Census Calculations.

14. VI:30. At the Office. The President came there. He had a Letter from J. Williams Chairman of the Military Committee of the Senate, saying that the Committee had taken a different view of the Law of 2. March 1821. (for reducing the army) from that entertained by the Executive; and that the Committee thought it respectful to the President that
that their Chairman should propose to the President a personal interview with him— And requesting him if it was desirable to him, to fix a day and hour when he Williams should call upon him— The President doubted whether he ought to receive Mr Williams—directed a Cabinet Meeting at 3— He spoke also of the nomination of A. Ware as District judge of Maine— District Court to be held the 26th— I said I should no longer object; but asked a copy of the paper signed by W. King, Holmes, Chandler, M. L. Hill, and Lincoln, declaring that Ware is the only man in the State, who will be acceptable to the People— He declined giving it— Cabinet Meeting at 3. All present except Wirt— The question was on Williams’s proposal— Unanimously held unprecedented, for a Committee to ask a direct communication with the President— And that the proposal should be declined— The question was of the manner. I thought the Secretary of War should answer. Calhoun objected that it would be offensive— The President proposed to send for Williams informally and tell him that he could not hold communication with a Committee of the Senate; which was approved— I had company to dine; and went with Mary Hellen, to Mrs Brown of Louisiana’s evening party.

15. VI:30.B. O. Tyler here with Certificate of Franklin Insurance Company Stock— W. P. Duval, to recommend W. Taylor to be transferred from Consular Agent at Carthagena, to the same Office at Vera Cruz— At the Office— Genl. J. P. Van Ness, to told me that his brother W. P. Van Ness District judge, for the Southern District of New-York, wants a Mission as Minister Plenipotentiary abroad, in South America, or at Lisbon. Major Roberdeau came with Cazenove, instead of Buck; about the discriminating duties against Hamburg. Agg came for a subscription for engraved Views on Hudson’s river, and Koetsier, a long bearded dutchman, with a proof that the epoct of the present year should be 6 instead of 7. At the President’s with the despatches from H. Middleton— The Communication from Poletica, of the Emperor of Russia’s decree about the North-west Coast. Hyde de Neuville’s new complaint against Lieutt. Stockton for visiting the Bombarde Julia, and G. Blake’s Letter on the case of the Portuguese vessel at Boston— Mr Floyd in H.R. has moved a Call for all the Russian Papers, and for more— I suggested to the President the necessity of remonstrating against the Russian Ukase— Of Answering the French Minister’s complaints against Stockton, and of sending an Agent to Mexico— Shaler’s name was mentioned— The President directed a Cabinet Meeting for to-morrow at 1. I mentioned to him Genl. Van Ness’s application for his brother—and also Mr Sanford’s claims to be considered— Evening at home— Census Calculations and Diary.

16. VI. At the Office. Genl P. B. Porter, going to Virginia. Mr Ruggles S.U.S. with Mr Hammond, Treasurer of the State, and J. C. Wright, district Attorney there— Cabinet Meeting— All present except Wirt— Crawford’s remarks against General Jackson— That there was no necessity for sending Callava to prison; that there was Courtesy due to him as a foreign
Officer, and that Jackson was not acting in a judicial capacity; because Mercad Vidal’s Affidavit concerning the papers was the day after Callava’s imprisonment— I remarked that the proceedings of Genl. Jackson, were founded upon the application of the Alcalde, and that was founded on the demand of Vidal—and that the commitment of Callava was for refusing to answer interrogatories— Hyde de Neuville’s last Note was discussed. A complaint against Lieutt. Stockton for visiting the French Bombarde Julie— Crawford was for disavowing the act, and paying for all the damages, from the contingent expenses of foreign intercourse—without process or trial. He was also for issuing instructions to the naval Officers if they took Pirates, with Prizes, to bring in the Pirates, but if the Prize, has negroes aboard, to let her go— I asked how if it should turn out upon adjudication, that the vessel taken for a Pirate was no Pirate— And our Office had released her prize, by his fiat alone, what then would follow? Crawford said, we gave our Officers authority to kill, and therefore need not scruple to give them that of letting a prize go— I said the authority to kill, was subject to subsequent trial and adjudication; but if the Executive of the United States should instruct their naval Officers, to let prizes go; without a trial, we should hear of it again— It was questioned whether a Court of Enquiry or Court Martial upon Stockton should be called— Determined to inform Stockton, and call for his Report—and I am to give Hyde a provisional answer— The President had a copy of Judge Story’s decision in the case of the Eugenie, and wants to direct an appeal from it to the Supreme Court, though it was given at the suggestion of the Executive— The President is stimulated from elsewhere— Case of the Portuguese ship at Boston— G. Blake’s Letter— Shall an appeal be directed from the judge’s Decision—to wait for the decision—first— An Agent to be sent to Mexico—resolved without discussion. W. Taylor to be transferred to Vera Cruz— At the Office— A. Ware’s Commission forwarded. Evening absorbed in calculations—

17. VI— At the Capitol—heard Sparks— Titus 2.11. Visits to Chief Justice Marshall; at Queen’s Hotel. Duval, Johnson, Todd and Story there— Coll. Pierson and Mr Wood came in— To Hopkinson and Ward at Miss Heyer’s— D. P. Cook there— To Mr Hammond and J. C. Wright at Brown’s Hotel— Met them and others at the door. At home. Letters to Josiah Quincy, and my Son Charles.

18. VI.Stewart’s Philosophy of the Human Mind. Vol. 2. H. W. Edwards here for his brother Alfred— Went to the President’s and came back with a note, directing a copy of Jacob Lewis’s charges against A. Edwards to be furnished him— At the Office. Bailey, with Torrey of Rhode-Island— Shaler— Proposed to him to go to Mexico— He asks advice what to do—gave him my opinion— Enquires what will be the
Salary? what allowance of expenses? whether for a Secretary? what expectation of permanent employment &c? He will see the President. Received another Note from P.U.S. about the answer to Hyde’s last complaint against lieutt. Stockton. Made a draft of the answer— Evening at Canning’s Ball; went with Dr Thornton. Anniversary of the Ratification of the Treaty of Ghent— Mrs Adams did not go. Chess, with Mrs Roberdeau— Supper— Fencing after— Home past Midnight. Snow-Storm all day— Cleared off late in the Evening

19. VII:15.B. O. Tyler here— Franklin Insurance Company Stock— Clay’s Portrait— Call on the Postmaster General— R. J. Meigs junr— Instructions to T. B. Johnson, to go to-morrow. Copy of the recommendation of S. Van Rensselaer as Postmaster at Albany, signed by 22. members of the New-York delegation.— At the Office— S. Canning— The rolled and hammered iron question— The claim of the Crooks’s— Wilcocke’s case— The Russian Edict about the North-west coast— discussion of an hour— W. Taylor— His claim to an appointment at Vera-Cruz— He is to call again— Dined with Messrs.Gaillard, Dickerson, Van Dyke, and Lowndes, at their Lodgings— Mr Crawford, the Baron de Neuville, and Mr Poletica, there— Also Mr Cuthbert of Georgia— Mr Randolph called this day at my house, and left his name.

20. VII.W. S. Cardell here— Academy of Language and Belles Lettres— Mr Canning— Mr Poletica—franking privilege? At the Office. Despatch from A. Gallatin of 27. Decr. Draft of Letter to Hyde de Neuville— At P.U.S. appointed meeting for to-morrow. Poletica’s communication. Jackson’s Letter— Dined at Hyde’s— A party of men— Madame de Neuville, unwell— Evening at the Drawing-room— Many Strangers— Talk with J. H. Eaton—about Genl. Jackson.

21. VI:30.Shaler at the Office— Talk of going to Mexico. His scruples— Inclines to decline. Cabinet Meeting— All present, except Wirt. Poletica’s notification concerning the North-West Coast— What to be done? Russian pretension to be resisted— Thompson proposes that enquiry should be first made of Poletica, upon what principle it is asserted; discussion upon this point— Ought we not to protest against it? and declare we will resist it— Resolutions of Congress advisable— Crawford thinks not— Because it would have the appearance of menace— Further to be considered— Answer to Anduaga to be prepared— Jackson’s Letter— Shall it be communicated to Anduaga, or to Congress? Crawford thinks to neither— I think it should be to Congress— Comity to foreign Ministers— Provocation given by Anduaga— Justice due to Jackson— P.U.S. returned to me corrected, the draft of Letter to Hyde— Draft to G. Walton concerning the returned Spanish Officers sent to P.U.S.— dined at S. Thompson’s Secy of the Navy— Ladies— Music after dinner— Evening idle.

22. VI:B. O. Tyler here— Franklin Insurance Company Stock. At the Office— W. Shaler— I told him what the President had said of his projected mission to Mexico— He concludes not to go— Took leave—going to New-York and Boston— To embark for Algiers. Letters to Walton, and to Genl. Jackson— Rhea of Tennessee here, at tea, this Evening— Washington’s Birth-day— Assembly Ball— We did not attend.

23. VI:30. Calculations, numbers and Logarithms— Morning flown— At the Office. J. H. Eaton—S.U.S. shewed him Jackson’s Letter in answer to Anduaga’s charges. Spoke of Heywood, as one of the first lawyers in the Union— His contempt for Fromentin— R. M. Johnson— About C. S. Todd’s accounts, and his return to the Spanish Main— Continuance of Todd’s Salary— Johnson said he would speak of it to P.U.S.— Stackelberg— Strange Story about a man named Edellijenta— Stackelberg has obtained leave of absence for a year— B. O. Tyler— To call again Monday— Torrey— General circulating Library project— We had company to dine— Ballard, Captain Baylies, Boyd, Genl. Bronaugh, Dr Brown James— Cuthbert, Finch Captain, Findley John, Gadsden Coll.Grafton, Hammond, Hubbard T. H.Ives, Maxcy, Middleton, A.Middleton, O. H.— Morse, Dr.Pierson, Plumer, Raymond, Ruggles, Stevenson, Stokes, Van Ness, J. P.Ward and Wright J. C. Those underscored sent excuses— Evening at Hyde de Neuville’s— Indians there. J. Randolph and G. M’Duffie— Scene between them in the House of Representatives this day— On petition of two Spanish Officers at Pensacola— Randolphs remark on the Indians— That he had some of their blood in his veins, and therefore took their part— Tazewell at the Office— His enquiries about the Florida Treaty.

24. VI:30. Heard Thacher the Methodist of New-Haven at the Capitol. Romans 8.2 [“]For the law of the Spirit of life in Christ Jesus hath made me free from the Law of Sin and Death”— Returned J. Randolph’s visit by Card— Call at Brown’s Hotel. W. Pinkney lying there, dangerously ill— Saw Commodore Rogers— Visits from Chief Justice Marshall, Judges Livingston and Story— Mail—despatches from H. Middleton. Dr and Mrs Eustis here after dinner. Eustis’s anxiety to get the Petition of the Spanish Officers out of the House— I told him what had been done— Returned him A. Eustis’s Letter— He spoke of providing for Genl. Gaines— Thought Brown had made money enough— M. L. Hill here— Had been at the President’s— His talk about J. Randolph— Application for Captain S. Tucker’s Grandson Hinds—

25. VI.B. O. Tyler here— Franklin Insurance Company Stock— At the Office. Letters from James Smith Wilcocks. At P.U.S.Thompson there— The President appointed a Cabinet Meeting for to-morrow at one O’Clock, about South-America. R. King at the Office— His concern about the rejection of Irish, by the Senate, as Marshal of the Western District of Pennsylvania— His alarm at Senatorial encroachment— Wyer came in after dinner, to say Mr Pinkney was a little better. J. Randolph announced to the House that Pinkney was dead, and said he was like Homer, Shakespear and Milton, an Unique—and moved the House to adjourn—and they did adjourn— George went to a party at Coll. Henderson’s—

26. VI:Morgan of New-York. H.R.U.S. here: to recommend G. D. Smith for a Consular appointment— Smith is a Grandson of the historian of New-York— Judge W. Johnson was here with a judge Vail of South-Carolina— Met C. J. Ingersoll, with his brother Edward Ingersoll. Cabinet Meeting at the President’s— Wirt only absent being yet unwell. Recognition of the South-Americans— The opinion that the time for recognition has arrived, unanimous— The President read a first draft of a Message, that he had prepared— Crawford, objected to an intimation contained in it, that by adopting the measure of recognition Spain might possibly take offence at it; and that we ought to be prepared for that event— Crawford thought it would be a hint to Spain to take offence, when she otherwise would not— That it would be represented in Congress, as inconsistent with the purport of the Message, and intended to defeat it; and that however recommended, no preparation would be made by Congress— Thompson partially supported the views of Crawford— Calhoun, strenuously opposed them; and thought the consequences of a War with Spain, ought to be distinctly presented in the Message— I concurred with Calhoun—the Message, I suggested should be sent with the papers in answer to H. Nelson’s call— De Neuville’s note of yesterday about La Pensée— No conclusion— I received a Letter from Amado Grehon about the Marianna Flora—drafted an answer— Blood, a Classmate of George’s, and Axel, dined with us— Dr. Huntt and H. Johnson of Louisiana S.U.S. here this Evening— Johnson Hellen taken very ill, with a fever— W. Pinkney S.U.S. died at 11. last Night—

27. VI. Funeral of W. Pinkney; Ryland’s Sermon and prayer at the Senate chamber. Mr Crawford rode with me to the burying grounds at the Navy yard— Told me several incidents historical, of 1813 and before—1811. and 12.—of Giles—J. Randolph—Mr Monroe, W. Pinkney and others— I walked, from the Capitol Hill to my Office— Note to Halkett— C. J. Ingersoll at the Office— Torrey, with his project for free circulating libraries, again declined subscribing— Mr and Mrs Frye spent the Evening here— Examination of my Accounts— Arrears of Waste Book 17. Months—began redeeming them— Johnson Hellen better, but yet confined to his bed.

28. VI: At the Office— Captain Ballard; came again about his charge against W. Shaler, upon the Department of State— Referred him to the Secretary of the Navy— Mr Halkett, concerning a claim of grant to Lord Selkirk, upon the red river, South of Latitude 49. and within the limits of U.S.—advised him to present a written memorial— C. J. Ingersoll Conversation— Anduaga’s railing at Philadelphia— W. Taylor here yesterday— Asked the cause of L. Harris’s enmity to me— Told him because I had been compelled to expose Harris’s dishonesty— Mr Canning—the question about rolled and hammered iron—to look up the papers, and see Mr Baldwin— Something about land-claims of British grants and pre-emption rights— Canning had the Bill, now pending in the Senate— I asked him to state his demands in writing— Calhoun—invitation to dine with P.U.S. to-morrow with the foreign Ministers—question of precedence, between the Heads of Departments and foreign Ministers—Seats at table— Calhoun and Thompson think it best not to go— P.U.S. spoke of the same question— Rejection of Irish as Marshal of the Western district of Pennsylvania— New Senatorial principle— King of Alabama, and King of New-York. The Senators of each State to dictate the appointments in it. The President strongly disapproves it— day absorbed at the Office by visitors— Company to dine— The judges, Marshall, Washington, Johnson, Todd, Duval and Story— Livingston sent an excuse— Caldwell, Child, Gouverneur Gray, Hamilton, Hoffman— C. J. Ingersoll— E. Ingersoll, Ringgold, and Wheaton were here. Baring, Brush, W. Foster, Harper, G. Hay, Insinger, M’Duffie, D. B. Ogden, J. Sergeant, Torrey, Webster and Winder, were invited, but sent excuses or did not come— Evening at Mrs Gales’s party—came home with Dr. and Mrs Thornton— Johnson Hellen convalescent.
